Problem:
Consider a function \(z(s)\) defined over the complex plane and involving a parameter \(s = x + yi\) (where \(i\) is the imaginary unit). We are particularly interested in investigating how the transformation \(H(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st} f(t) \, dt\) (a Laplace transform) behaves with changes in the function \(f(t)\) used in the transform.

If \(f(t)\) is changed to \(f(t) + g(t)\) without any intervention in the variable \(s\) or \(t\), will \(H(s)\) merely become the sum of the Laplace transforms of \(f(t)\) and \(g(t)\)?
Explanation: The linearity of the Laplace transform ensures that the transform of the sum of two functions is the sum of their transforms, i.e., \(H(s) = \mathcal{L}\{f(t) + g(t)\} = \mathcal{L}\{f(t)\} + \mathcal{L}\{g(t)\}\). Therefore, changing \(f(t)\) to \(f(t) + g(t)\) adds the transforms directly.
